abstract: The decision by EADS to bid for a contract worth at least $35 billion came six weeks after its partner, Northrop Grumman, dropped out of the contest.
snippet: The decision by EADS to bid for a contract worth at least $35 billion came six weeks after its partner, Northrop Grumman, dropped out of the contest.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon’s long-running effort to buy aerial refueling tankers for the Air Force took another twist on Tuesday when a European company decided that instead of walking away, it would compete with Boeing for a contract worth at least $35 billion.

headline.main: Airbus’s Parent Gambles on Tanker Contract
headline.print_headline: Boeing Faces Tanker Rival After All
